cab.content: LABOUR POSITION IN MUNITION INDUSTRIES,(7th August 1918,)I circulate the following notes which have been prepared in the Intelligence and Statistics Section of the Ministry of. Munitions on the labour position in munitionStatistics or the Week ending the 31st July 1918.During the week ending the 31st July, 92,489 working days or nearly three-fifths of 1 per cent, of the possible working time were lost through strikes on Ministry of Munitions work.The strike against the Ministry's embargo policy"5' at Coventry, Rugby, Bir-mingham, and in a few workshops at Newcastle and South Shields, caused the loss of 79,350 working days in this week by a total of 31,850 workers.At Sheffield a strike of 1,700 moulders, which, began on the 15th July against an arbitration award, caused this week a loss of 10,200 days.The Committee of Inquiry.The following gentlemen have been appointed to serve on the Munitions Labour Committee of Inquiry, appointed to report on the questions raised in the course of the recent embargo strike:-Mr. Justice McCardie, Chairman; Sir Stephenson Kent, K.C.B., Ministry of Munitions ; Sir David Shackleton, K.C.B., Ministry of Labour ; Sir Robert Home, K.B.E., Admiralty ; Sir Allan Smith, K.B.E., Sir Herbert Rowell, K.B.E., and Mr. F. Dudley Docker, C.B.E., nominated by the Engineering Employers' Advisory Committee of the Ministry of Munitions ; Mr. J. Kaylor, Mr. G. Wilkinson, and Mr. W. F. Dawtry, nominated by the Trade Union Advisory Committee of the Ministry of Munitions; and Mr. C. S. Hurst, Secretary. The first meeting of the committee took place on the 2nd August, and other meetings are being held as frequently as possible.* Tins strike began in the week ending the 24th July at Coventry, Rugby, and Leicester, when 21,600 working days were lost and 13,200 workers were affected. The strike at Leicester lasted only half a day. The total number of persons who struck on account of the embargo between the 23rd and the 27th July was about 35,050. The time lost on account of the embargo dispute was nearly fths of 1 per - cent, of the time which should normally have been worked throughout the country during the five days of the strike.industries.WINSTON S.
